Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI: Evaluating the Molecular Genetic Pathways Responsible for Stable Host: Symbiont Interactions in Sponge:Algal Associations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intracellular associations between animal hosts and algal symbionts support important ecosystems like coral reefs. Despite the importance of these associations, there is limited understanding of basic aspects about how stable interactions between host and algal partners is achieved. This inhibits our ability to make informed decisions about the management of vulnerable ecosystems. For example, coral reefs experience periodic bleaching events that involve the breakdown of the symbiosis and jeopardize reef health, but the process of bleaching and subsequent recovery of the host are poorly understood. To protect our valuable reef resources, greater understanding of the cellular and genetic cross-talk between symbiotic partners is required. This project will elucidate key components of the conserved genetic regulatory pathways important in host:symbiont exchanges. As changes to ocean environments occur (e.g., increasing average seawater temperatures), it is imperative that details about how hosts support symbiont populations at the cellular and genetic level are fully understood. The project has a diverse suite of planned broader impacts including training of STEM undergraduates, involvement in a pre-college summer bridge program to increase diversity in STEM, partnerships with national leaders in incorporating undergraduate research in community colleges, and high impact community based learning opportunities.

The research will refine understanding of host:symbiont interactions through identification of major-effect symbiosis genes and genetic pathways. The proposed work takes advantage of unique properties of marine and freshwater sponge hosts and their algal partners to identify the molecular, genetic, cellular, and physiological interactions that occur. These properties allow control over the timing of symbiont infection, so that gene expression profiles can be correlated with events involved with symbiont contact, engulfment, recognition, intracellular migration, and repopulation. In a methodologically novel way, the research will create different combinations of hosts and algal partners to explore reasons why particular hosts become suitable habitat for particular symbionts while other hosts cannot support those symbionts. The project will explore how down-regulating gene expression can change dynamics of host:symbiont interactions, and combining field-based experiments, RNAseq, and advanced physiological, microscopic, and molecular tools, the research will identify common regulatory features of those interactions. The results will increase understanding of the habitat requirements of the symbiont, and the ability of the hosts to interact with different partners. The results will also help define the scope of change in the identity of symbiotic partners. In addition to intellectual contributions in the form of publications and presentations, this project will expand educational and research opportunities for pre-college, community college, and undergraduate students, particularly those from underserved backgrounds. The proposal will support high impact practices like course-based research and community-based learning in the context of an undergraduate curriculum, as well as community outreach through a multi-disciplinary faculty learning community and civic-engaged talks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the work was to identify major symbiosis-effect genes/genetic pathways regulated during establishment of symbiont populations within a host. Through the comparison of two dissimilar host:algal partnerships, the research also afforded the opportunity to look for evidence of convergent evolution in genetic pathways co-opted for intracellular residency and to functionally interrogate genes-of-major-effect. Using different sponge-symbiont combinations (typical and atypical symbionts in the same host background), the regulation of interactions at holobiont, physiological, cellular, and genetic levels were monitored. A manuscript is in preparation from a large-scale ocean acidification experiment involving Cliona varians and its Gerakladium symbionts that was supported by funding from this grant and was conducted by our post-doc who was supported by a Marie Curie Fellowship. In addition, freshwater and marine symbioses were experimentally re-established from aposymbiotic hosts and isolated algae and transcriptomes were sequenced. The Ephydatia muelleri genome consortium, EphyBase, published a manuscript and genome tools for the scientific community, and transcriptomic resources have been shared on at Ephybase: https://era.library.ualberta.ca/items/74f2602c-56df-4577-9a1b-573c55a88c54. This project (and co-PI Hill) contributed significantly to that manuscript and data sets in the area of describing symbioses in Ephydatia, providing gemmules, and transcriptomic data sets. This funded project benefited from obtaining access to the annotated genome for more robust analysis of the RNASeq data. The Co-PI is a co-author on this Nature Communications paper that included images and information about the algal symbiosis obtained from this grant work. A manuscript on methods describing the isolating and culturing of symbiotic microalgae from freshwater sponges was published in Protocol.io. A manuscript establishing Ephydatia:green algae as a tractable model to study intracellular symbioses was published in PeerJ. This manuscript focused on differential gene expression 24 hours post infection and highlighted possible convergent pathways to intracellular symbiosis. Following this work, gene expression profiles for sponges exposed to live algae, heat-killed algae, and bacteria have been compared, and differential regulation of specific genes (e.g., ABCC transporter) when sponges are presented with homologous versus heterologous symbiont infections. Additionally, Ephydatia metagenomes from multiple geographic locations are also being sequenced. Algal partners between E. muelleri populations from Maine, Virginia, and Canada are not identical species. Finally, a deterministic model and an agent-based model have been developed to interrogate theoretical aspects of host:symbiont population dynamics. In our models, two symbionts compete for access to a single host in the presence and absence of mathematical coefficients that emulate the effects of mutualism. The results from this work are being prepared for a publication that will be submitted to PNAS in 2021. The COVID pandemic effected the ability to finish aspects of the work by the end of the grant period. The work continues but the 4hr transcriptome paper and the modeling paper would likely have already been submitted in the absence of COVID delays. COVID also delayed the work because access to the lab was restricted for several months, and students could not be employed for a period of time as safe work practices were implemented. COVID also distracted collaborators who needed to prepare for pandemic teaching.

The broader impacts of the work integrated aspects of this research project into undergraduate courses, provided mentored research experiences for many undergraduate students (particularly students from minoritized backgrounds), and formed a collaboration with community colleges to introduce aspects of freshwater sponge research into their curriculum and undergraduate research experiences. Key outcomes include mentorship of 26 undergraduate research students (69% identify as women, 58% identify as students of color and 19% identify as Black). A new first-year student course-based research experience was developed around this project. The course, called BIO 195 Lab-Based Biological Inquiry: Symbiotic Microalgae has three sections and enrolled close to 60 students who were all engaged in experiments centered on this research project. In a partnership with Dr. James Hewlett and the CCURI project, freshwater sponges were developed as a research model for community colleges and high schools resulted in numerous workshops where faculty were trained to identify, collect, and work with freshwater sponges. The experimental frameworks design as a part of this partnership were included in a new laboratory manual, "Biotech in your backyard: Experiments from backyard to classroom." (http://biomanufacturing.org/teacherresources/high-school-teacher-resources/biotech-in-your-backyard-experiments-from-backyard-to-classroom). These projects also led to contributions to the Sponge Barcoding Project (https://www.spongebarcoding.org/).
